docs.snippet: When Megawati Sukarnoputri made her first major speech as president of Indonesia in August, she apologized for abuses committed by soldiers fighting separatist rebels.  ''We need a security force which is effective, highly disciplined and under th...
docs.lead_paragraph: When Megawati Sukarnoputri made her first major speech as president of Indonesia in August, she apologized for abuses committed by soldiers fighting separatist rebels. ''We need a security force which is effective, highly disciplined and under the control of the government,'' she said. Mrs. Megawati has so far done nothing to correct the behavior of Indonesia's military or police. Their brutal conduct is partly responsible for the conflict in Aceh, the longest-running, most violent and most important of Indonesia's several separatist conflicts. Throughout the 50 years of Aceh's on-and-off war, Indonesia's leaders have made several efforts at a compromise solution. But the conduct of the country's security forces has left the Acehnese unlikely to accept one.
docs.abstract: Tina Rosenberg Editorial Observer column cites role played by brutal, undisciplined and underfunded military and paramilitary units in long separatist conflict in Aceh, Indonesia; notes many of abuses are committed for money, with paramilitary police supplementing meager pay with extortion and kidnapping (M)

headline.main: Editorial Observer; A Guerrilla War Stoked by a Thirst for Cash

docs.snippet: A secret document is a sexy thing, a sort of striptease whose lure is less what it reveals than the aching promise. Bogoljub Bjelica, president of the Committee for the Freedom of Slobodan Milosevic, would allow the briefest peep of a United State...
docs.lead_paragraph: A secret document is a sexy thing, a sort of striptease whose lure is less what it reveals than the aching promise. Bogoljub Bjelica, president of the Committee for the Freedom of Slobodan Milosevic, would allow the briefest peep of a United States government file that he got his hands on and that he expects may make its way to Mr. Milosevic's trial for war crimes. ''The answer to the question, 'Who produced war in the Balkans?' must be found,'' said Mr. Bjelica, suggesting conspiratorially that the answer lay in hidden files like this one. ''President Milosevic, during all these years, was doing everything to prove the truth. He is doing the same now in The Hague. And he will prove the truth.''
docs.abstract: Focus on controversy over source of information being tapped by former Serbian leader Slobodan Milosevic, being tried for war crimes in the Hague; he seems to have good and accurate information about everything in cross-examining witnesses; claims information is obtained from associates in Serbia, process lawyers describe as organic telephone tree of informers, including some Albanians, who pass along bits of information as testimony unfolds; weekly Serbian newspaper having close contacts with state security official suggests otherwise; reports Milosevic transferred thousands of Army documents to his own archives before losing power in October 2000; photo (M)

headline.main: Belgrade Journal; Milosevic Spouts Facts. Who's Spilling Secrets?

docs.snippet: Rudolph Davila, who was awarded the Medal of Honor 56 years after he saved the lives of 130 American soldiers by rushing a German machine gun outpost in Italy in World War II, died Jan. 26 at his home in Vista, Calif. He was 85.    The cause was c...
docs.lead_paragraph: Rudolph Davila, who was awarded the Medal of Honor 56 years after he saved the lives of 130 American soldiers by rushing a German machine gun outpost in Italy in World War II, died Jan. 26 at his home in Vista, Calif. He was 85. The cause was cancer, his family said.
docs.abstract: Rudolph Davila, Medal of Honor winner for heroics during World War II, dies at age 85; photo (M)

headline.main: Rudolph Davila, 85, Recipient Of Highest Award for Valor

docs.snippet: A Roman Catholic priest pleaded not guilty to charges of genocide and crimes against humanity at the United Nations war crimes tribunal for Rwanda. The Rev. Athanase Seromba, who has been a priest in Florence, Italy, since 1997, surrendered Wednes...
docs.lead_paragraph: A Roman Catholic priest pleaded not guilty to charges of genocide and crimes against humanity at the United Nations war crimes tribunal for Rwanda. The Rev. Athanase Seromba, who has been a priest in Florence, Italy, since 1997, surrendered Wednesday to the court, in Arusha, Tanzania. Father Seromba, 37, a member of Rwanda's Hutu majority, is charged with ordering Hutu extremists to kill thousands of minority Tutsi in April 1994 by bulldozing his parish church in Nyange, where the Tutsi had taken refuge during the ethnic massacres.

headline.main: World Briefing | Africa: Rwanda: 'Not Guilty' Plea At Tribunal

docs.snippet: Throughout Asia and in much of the world recently, contemporary Japan has become as famous for its history textbooks that obscure, or even white-out, unpleasant facts as it is for its wealth or fading industrial prowess.    How does one explain, t...
docs.lead_paragraph: Throughout Asia and in much of the world recently, contemporary Japan has become as famous for its history textbooks that obscure, or even white-out, unpleasant facts as it is for its wealth or fading industrial prowess. How does one explain, then, the extraordinary popularity of a 900-page history of the immediate post-war period that, among many other uncomfortable topics, assigns guilt to Emperor Hirohito and explores the role of politicians and organized crime in prostituting Japanese women to United States soldiers?
docs.abstract: Embracing Defeat, John W Dower's history of Japan's immediate postwar period, has become best-seller in Japan, where history of 40's and 50's has either been glossed over, whitewashed or subjected to sterile polemics of right and left; five Japanese readers of different generations and backgrounds discuss revelations they received from book; photos (M)

headline.main: An Outsider Teaches Japan About Itself

docs.snippet: President Paul Kagame said he was optimistic about reviving ties between Angola and Rwanda, backers of opposing sides in the war in Congo. Speaking after returning from a two-day visit to Luanda at the invitation of President José Eduardo dos San...
docs.lead_paragraph: President Paul Kagame said he was optimistic about reviving ties between Angola and Rwanda, backers of opposing sides in the war in Congo. Speaking after returning from a two-day visit to Luanda at the invitation of President José Eduardo dos Santos, Mr. Kagame said the aims of the trip had been to look at ways to repair relations and to discuss the Congo peace effort. ''In my judgment the discussion was very good, the results were very good,'' he said. ''We were very well received and we had very frank and cordial discussions, I believe with good results, but we have to keep working together.'' Angola, Namibia and Zimbabwe have backed Congo's government in a civil war that erupted in 1998. Rwanda, Burundi and Uganda have supported rebels.
docs.abstract: Pres Paul Kagame of Rwanda says he is optimistic about reviving ties between Angola and Rwanda, backers of opposing sides in war in Congo; photo (S)

headline.main: World Briefing | Africa: Rwanda: Talks With Angola

docs.snippet: The Khartoum Hilton was fully booked this week.    The city's conference center was packed. Taxi drivers were earning pocketfuls of dinars shuttling all the visitors around....
docs.lead_paragraph: The Khartoum Hilton was fully booked this week. The city's conference center was packed. Taxi drivers were earning pocketfuls of dinars shuttling all the visitors around.
docs.abstract: International Conference on Eradication of Dracunculiasis, commonly known as Guinea worm disease, draws hundreds of scientists, politicians and others to Khartoum, Sudan; Guinea worm disese occurs in just 13 countries around world and could be eradicated altogether if it were not for Sudan, country with more cases than any other; health experts note that Sudan has 80 percent of world's reported Guinea worm cases, virtually all of them in war-ravaged south where clinics are rarity and aerial bombardments by government troops are commonplace; 18-year-long war in Sudan has made impossible inoculations, treatments and health education campaigns that are imperative in controlling any disease; photo; map showing cases of Guinea worm disease worldwide (M)

headline.main: Sudan's War Bars Cure For Disease Eradicated In Other Parts of Africa

docs.snippet: Usmaan Ahmad, a 26-year-old American graduate student of Kashmiri descent, learned again last week why it has been so difficult to find a political settlement for Kashmir, the Himalayan territory in dispute between India and Pakistan.    Mr. Ahmad...
docs.lead_paragraph: Usmaan Ahmad, a 26-year-old American graduate student of Kashmiri descent, learned again last week why it has been so difficult to find a political settlement for Kashmir, the Himalayan territory in dispute between India and Pakistan. Mr. Ahmad is studying international law and conflict resolution at the Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy at Tufts University. He had planned to go to Katmandu, Nepal, for a meeting today through Wednesday of Indian, Pakistani and Kashmiri academics, artists and human rights advocates to discuss peaceful political initiatives for ending the crisis over Kashmir.
docs.abstract: Interview with Usmaan Ahmad, 26-year-old American graduate student of Kashmiri descent who is spearheading efforts by group of Indian, Pakistani and Kashmiri academics, artists and human rights advocates to find peaceful settlement to conflict over Kashmir but is meeting resistance from India and extremists in Kashmiri rebel movement (M)

headline.main: Kashmir's Champion Finds Pitfalls to Peace

docs.snippet: As part of reconciliation efforts on the divided island of Cyprus, the Greek Cypriots have asked the United Nations to help dispose of an weapons cache collected in the early 1970's in anticipation of war against the Turkish Cypriots. The request ...
docs.lead_paragraph: As part of reconciliation efforts on the divided island of Cyprus, the Greek Cypriots have asked the United Nations to help dispose of an weapons cache collected in the early 1970's in anticipation of war against the Turkish Cypriots. The request followed the first week of formal reunification talks between President Glafcos Clerides and Rauf Denktash, the Turkish Cypriot leader. The Greek Cypriots have also asked the United Nations to begin clearing the estimated 17,000 mines along the line that has separated the two groups since 1974. Douglas Frantz (NYT)
docs.abstract: Greek Cypriots, in reconciliation effort, ask United Nations to help dispose of weapons cache collected in early 1970's in anticipation of war with Turkish Cypriots and to begin clearing mines along line that has separated two groups since 1974 (S)

headline.main: World Briefing | Europe: Cyprus: A Gesture Of Peace

docs.snippet: The Bush administration today voiced support for President Andrés Pastrana's ultimatum to leftist rebels in Colombia, even as officials and experts expressed misgivings that it could lead to further violence and disrupt counternarcotics efforts. ...
docs.lead_paragraph: The Bush administration today voiced support for President Andrés Pastrana's ultimatum to leftist rebels in Colombia, even as officials and experts expressed misgivings that it could lead to further violence and disrupt counternarcotics efforts. Secretary of State Colin L. Powell laid blame on the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, or FARC, for the collapse of peace talks after three years and for Mr. Pastrana's order that rebels vacate a demilitarized area within 48 hours.
docs.abstract: Bush administration voices support for Pres Andres Pastrana's ultimatum to leftist rebels in Colombia, even as officials and experts express misgivings that it could lead to further violence and disrupt counternarcotics efforts; Secretary of State Colin L Powell lays blame on rebel group, FARC, for collapse of peace talks after three years; administration officials have backed peace talks because they have concluded that Colombia's security forces are incapable of victory over 17,000-member FARC; but they acknowledge that Pastrana has nothing to show for negotiations and that rebels have little incentive to make deal (M)

headline.main: U.S. Supports Colombian On Ultimatum to Rebels
